description: Patola is a double ikat woven sari made from silk, known for its intricate geometric and figurative patterns. Each piece takes 4-6 months to complete, making it one of the most expensive saris in India.
preservation_efforts: NGO support and government initiatives for artisan training|Documentation of traditional techniques|Exhibition support

description: Kawad is a portable shrine with multiple folding panels painted with religious stories. Used by storytellers called Kawadiya Bhats, this art form combines visual art with oral traditions.
preservation_efforts: State handicraft promotion|Workshops for young artisans|Museum collections

description: Aranmula Kannadi is a handmade metal mirror crafted from a special alloy. The craft is protected under Geographical Indication and is made only in Aranmula village.
Nakshi Kantha is a type of embroidered quilt that tells stories through intricate stitching patterns. Traditionally made from old saris and dhotis, each piece is unique.
preservation_efforts: Self-help groups|Design innovation workshops|Online marketplace support

description: Athangudi tiles are handmade cement tiles known for their vibrant colors and unique patterns. Made only in Athangudi village, these eco-friendly tiles use local materials.
Dhokra is an ancient lost-wax casting technique used to create intricate brass and bronze sculptures. Each piece is unique and carries tribal motifs.
preservation_efforts: Tribal art promotion|Skill transfer programs|Exhibition platforms

description: Chamba Rumal is a square handkerchief with intricate embroidery depicting mythological scenes and folk tales. Known for its double-sided precision.
Kinhal toys and religious idols are made from lightweight wood and painted with vegetable dyes. Known for their distinctive style and eco-friendly nature.
